reviews.review_text: Anyone who wants to join the military should read this book. A must read for everyone who thinks war is glorious!

This book was well written and gave me an insight into the Vietnam war and war in general that I never knew or understood.  Should be read by more people, especially people not familiar with the military.
Can easily relate to complete change in range of emotions from embarking through tour and leaving
If you only read one book this is the one!
A great account of personal experiences in an unfortunate war.

I read this book while I was going through Officer Candidate School during the summer of 1975.  I realize that it is a piece of of very good fiction but it does bring many memories of my time in the USMC.  I decided to read it again, this time on a Kindle.  I found the book to be a solid recollection of many memories, I do not know what was real and what was recreated from others memories.

I bought this book when it first came out while I was a junior in high school. I made a career out of the military and it went with me all over the world and I still have it.  It's one of my favorite books. Does anyone remember what happened when we left Vietnam? How many thousands were executed? Do we just let evil prevail? This book also reminds me  why I made the military a career.

As a combat veteran it was difficult to read. At the end I found myself feeling tied in a knot. However it encouraged me to return to therapy. I give thanks for how it stirred me to once again seek help in healing the unseen wounds of war.

summary:
The classic Vietnam memoir, as relevant today as it was almost thirty years ago.

In March of 1965, Marine Lieutenent Philip J. Caputo landed at Da Nang with the first ground combat unit deployed to Vietnam. Sixteen months later, having served on the line in one of modern history's ugliest wars, he returned home―physically whole but emotionally wasted, his youthful idealism forever gone. 

A Rumor of War is more than one soldier's story. Upon its publication in 1977, it shattered America's indifference to the fate of the men sent to fight in the jungles of Vietnam. In the years since then, it has become not only a basic text on the Vietnam War but also a renowned classic in the literature of wars throughout history and, as Caputo explains, of "the things men do in war and the things war does to men."

"A singular and marvelous work." New York Times

“Caputo's troubled, searching meditations on the love and hate of war, on fear, and the ambivalent discord warfare can create in the hearts of decent men, are among the most eloquent I have read in modern literature.” William Styron, New York Review of Books
